Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: the bedroom
The eastern bedroom.

This is one of the mansion's private bedrooms. A couple of curtained windows provide good views of the back lawn, dark in the night. The head of a low bed is placed against the south wall; a low dresser is placed under the east window, with a chair before it.
http://www.skotos.net/MansionGame/images/BedroomEast.jpg
the southern door
Near the western end of the southern wall is a panelled oak door. A brass knob and lock are attached to the edge of the door.
the western door
Set in the western wall is a panelled oak door. A brass knob is attached to the edge of the door.
the low, simple bed

This low, simple oak wooden bedframe has two ends -- the head and the foot; four legs support the corners. The head and foot barely rise above the bedding. Sheets, pillows, and blankets are lying on the mattress.
A low, simple bed.
A low oak bed.
the low bed's foot end
The foot of the bed is low and wide.
The low, wide foot of the bed.
low bed's head end
One end of a low bed is a wide, arched wooden headframe, pushed up against the south wall.
The arched head of the simple bedframe.
the low bed's legs
The legs of the low wooden bed are square oak posts.
The legs of this low bed are unpainted wooden posts.
the tan wool blanket
This is large, square blanket, made from soft, tan wool. It is lying on the bed sheets.
A large, soft tan wool blanket on the bed.
the edge of a wool blanket
The four edges of the soft, tan blanket are each about eight feet long.
The four edges of the square wool blanket.
the wool blanket's center
The broad center of the soft, tan wool blanket.
The broad center of a tan wool blanket.
the comfortable armchair

This heavy, comfortable craftsman-style armchair is built from cherry-stained oak, with dark brown leather-covered cushions and padding on the seat, back and arms. The leather is attached to the frame with smooth, dark brass rivets. The chair is standing in the eastern end of the room, before the low dresser.
A comfortable, leather-upholstered oak armchair, standing in the eastern end of the room.
the armchair's arm
Both arms of this comfortable armchair are cushioned with dark brown leather, held to the frame by smooth, dark brass rivets.
The arms of this comfortable armchair are leather padded.
the back of an comfortable armchair
The broad back of this comfortable armchair is cushioned with dark brown leather, held to the frame by smooth, dark brass rivets.
The back of the armchair is cushioned with leather.
the armchair's leg
The four legs of the comfortable armchair are square, carved from cherry-stained oak in a craftsman style.
The legs of the comfortable armchair are angular cherry-stained oak.
the armchair's upholstery rivets
The comfortable armchair's seat, back and arms are covered in dark brown leather, secured along the edges with smooth, dark brass rivets.
The comfortable armchair's leather cushions and paddings are attached with smooth, dark brass rivets.
the comfortable armchair's seat
The comfortable armchair's seat is covered in smooth dark brown leather, secured along the edges with smooth, dark brass rivets.
The comfortable armchair's seat is cushioned with brown leather.
the east curtains
The heavy fabric of the curtains around the eastern window are swept back by brass hold-backs.
the north curtains
The heavy fabric of the curtains around the northern window are swept back by brass hold-backs.
the low oak dresser

This is a low dresser, built in a simple craftsman style of dark, cherry-stained oak. This is a massive glass-fronted bookcase, about four feet tall, made in a simple, massive craftsman style of dark, cherry-stained oak. It has six drawers; dark metal pulls can be used to open them.
A low cherry-stained oak dresser, with several drawers.
the low dresser's top
The top of a low, cherry-stained oak dresser.
The top of a low wooden dresser.
the curtain holdbacks
The heavy fabric of the curtains around the windows are swept back by hold-backs: curved brass hooks mounted low on the edges of the windows.
the edge of a white pillow
The four edges of the white, down-filled silk pillow are each about three feet long.
The four edges of an white silk pillow.
white silk pillow's center
The broad center of a white silk pillow is soft and comfortable.
The center of a white silk pillow.
the white silk pillows
There are two pale white pillows on the bed, each made of smooth silk and filled with swansdown.
A pair of white silk pillows on the bed, filled with down.
the white linen bedsheets
This are two bedsheets, made of fine bleached linen, about eight feet square. They are normally laid on the bed below the blanket.
White linen bedsheets lying on the bed.
the edge of a white bedsheet
The four edges of the two white linen bedsheets are each about eight feet long.
The edges of the white bedsheets on the bed.
the center of the white bedsheets
This is the center of a white linen bedsheet.
The center of the white linen bedsheets on the bed.
the view of the lawn through the eastern window
Through the eastern window, you can see:
Through the eastern window, you can see:
the view of the rear lawn through the northern window
Through the northern window, you can see:
Through the northern window, you can see:
the east wall

Carefully panelled oak wainscotting rises to about six feet high on the east wall of the bedroom; cream-colored plaster covers the remainder of the wall, up to the ceiling cornice. A curtained window is set in the northern half, looking out onto the dark back lawn. A low dresser is placed under the window.
the north wall

Carefully panelled oak wainscotting rises to about six feet high on the north wall of the bedroom; cream-colored plaster covers the remainder of the wall. A curtained window is set in the middle of this wall; past the clean, reflective glass you have a view of the dark back lawn.
the south wall

Carefully panelled oak wainscotting rises to about six feet high on the south wall of the bedroom; cream-colored plaster covers the remainder of the wall, up to the ceiling cornice. An oak panelled door is set in the western end of this wall. The head of a low bed is placed against the south wall.
the west wall

Carefully panelled oak wainscotting rises to about six feet high on the west wall of the bedroom; cream-colored plaster covers the remainder of the wall, up to the ceiling cornice. An oak-panelled door is set in this wall.
the curtained east window
A window is set in the east wall; white curtains are swept back from the window by brass hold-backs. A low dresser is standing under the window. The window looks out onto the eastern lawn.
the curtained north window
A window is set in the middle of the north wall; white curtains are swept back from the window by brass hold-backs. The window looks out onto the rear lawn.

Notes:Category.Notes:Note: One of the two bedrooms of the mansion.
